          • ana53294 says:
            January 27, 2020 at 12:45 pm

            What Matt M says. Besides, why should it take that long for a check, once the information is inputed electronically, to be validated? Bank transfers are usually done in a couple of hours. Even international bank transfers with different currencies take less than two working days.

            Why would it take more than two working days to take the amount of money from the check writer’s account and transfer it to the person who cashed the check?

            I agree that maybe demanding that a check be cashed immediately means it cannot be verified, but 2 days should be enough. There is no reason whatsoever, other than some convoluted banking, why it would take that long.

            I assume nobody would be stupid enough to accept checks from countries like Russia (where there is a genuine problem with international transfers due to sanctions) or Greece (capital controls).

          • EchoChaos says:
            January 27, 2020 at 12:47 pm

            @Matt M

            This one I actually suspect is primarily for consumers.

            If you write me a check, I deposit it and then need twenty bucks of that tomorrow, I really don’t want to hear that the bank is still verifying the transaction and neither of us can use that money right now.

            Banks are fine with taking the time to verify since they are the ones who benefit from the float by having a pile of money that neither of us can use for a short period.

            Now, obviously making banks entirely not liable is probably from the bank’s perspective, but in this case I think it’s reasonable.

          • Matt M says:
            January 27, 2020 at 12:48 pm

            I‚Äôm betting the 24 hour availability law was made against the banks‚Äô wishes, as a response to banks holding funds for unreasonable amounts of time because of course they don‚Äôt want to let go of the funds if they don‚Äôt have to.

            Plausible.

            But the added kicker of “Oh but if the check doesn’t clear, in two weeks, we can claw the money back from the depositor” seems like the absolute worst sort of “compromise” between big business and the state where they both get a little bit of what they want, while the consumer gets hosed.

          • Matt M says:
            January 27, 2020 at 12:51 pm

            If you write me a check, I deposit it and then need twenty bucks of that tomorrow, I really don‚Äôt want to hear that the bank is still verifying the transaction and neither of us can use that money right now.

            But you’re fine with the bank calling you up two weeks later and saying “By the way, that check you cashed, it was fraudulent. You now owe us $20. We took it out of your account, but you over-drafted, so that’ll be an additional $40 fee. And if you don’t pay by tomorrow, we’re sending you to collections, which will damage your credit score?”

            Maybe I’m just too conservative (in the literal, non-political sense) but I’d rather be told “Thanks for this deposit, you will receive the money as soon as we have verified this is a good check” and wait rather than be told “Here’s your money” with the chance that at some unknown point in the future, the bank will say, “Whoops! Changed our mind!”

          • EchoChaos says:
            January 27, 2020 at 12:55 pm

            @Matt M

            I totally 100% agree with you.

            The banks, not being stupid and able to put pressure on said Congresscritters, put the liability on those same people in situation A.

            However, if I had to choose whether or not to sign up for this feature if it was optional, I’d probably sign up for it unreservedly. I mostly do business with people I trust and the advantage of having the money available immediately outweighs the risks of it in almost all cases.

          • Theodoric says:

            @acymetric

            I once deposited a check, saw the funds available on the bank’s website, transferred the funds, then had the check bounce and got hit with fees and had to reimburse the bank. At no time was there any disclaimer on the bank’s website to the effect of “Hey, this check has not cleared, transfer funds at your own risk.” They really should be required to put some sort of notation as to whether it cleared or not.

            Money appearing in your account after a few days (clearing) does not mean the check was good. That can take a few weeks. Scammers will absolutely take advantage of the fact that not everyone knows that.

          • VoiceOfTheVoid says:

            While the worst case (scam check seems to clear, bank claws you for the money 2 weeks later when it turns out to be fraudulent, after you spent it) is much worse in the current system then under a hypothetical “banks take however long they need to verify before funds are available” system, the typical case (you deposit your paycheck and have the funds to pay your bills within a day) is much better.

          • acymetric says:

            @VoiceOfTheVoid

          • Edward Scizorhands says:
            January 28, 2020 at 10:06 am

            Besides, why should it take that long for a check, once the information is inputed electronically, to be validated?

            You go on vacation for 3 weeks. The first day, someone does a really good forgery of a check against your bank account for $200,000. The funds “clear” in a few days, because the check is legitimately against your account and the funds are in there.

            You get back 3 weeks later. You want your money back.

            The way to handle this is to unwind everything. The scammers know this is going to be unwound. That is why they are so desperate to get a sucker to do something that cannot be unwound.

            With each day, the chances of a check deposit being unwound decrease, but in the situation I just described, it might take a while for the victim to find out and unwind things. But there is no point at which they can say “yes, we can guarantee that there is no fraud going on here.” The one with the best knowledge of that is the check depositor. They may not want the knowledge, but any other situation is nuts.

          • hls2003 says:
            January 28, 2020 at 12:13 pm

            Just so everyone is clear, all of this in the U.S. is generally governed by the Uniform Commercial Code, or UCC. These are a common set of laws governing commercial and financial transactions which have been enacted as state law by almost all of the states in the U.S. There are multiple chapters of the UCC, including, among others, commercial paper (checks and other financial transactions), banking, secured transactions (chattel liens and security interests), and sales of goods.

            So for example the time it takes a check to truly “clear” is ultimately going to be governed by the statute of limitations for every interested party who could challenge the transaction. I believe an account holder has 30 days after receiving their account statement to notify their bank of an improperly paid check; so depending where you are in the calendar monthly statement cycle, it could be something like 59 days. Checks routinely clear more quickly than that in practice, but the final deadlines for each transaction, and the respective rights of each party thereto (maker, payor, payee, holder in due course, etc.) can be painstakingly assembled by working your way through the UCC. It is very dense but does ultimately give the answers you’re looking for.

            I don’t know what all those answers are offhand because I don’t deal with it often enough, but although the UCC does ultimately have some policy rationales (e.g. holders in due course are almost always protected; the party best situated to detect fraud usually gets liability allocated to them; etc.) in the end a functioning financial system just requires rules that are clear much more than rules that are purely “fair” in a given circumstance.

          • CatCube says:
            January 28, 2020 at 1:03 pm

            @hls2000

            You say “almost all states in the U.S.” Wouldn’t that also open the possibility that the time it takes to clear a check would depend upon which state each party is in? If one of the parties to this transaction might be in a state that doesn’t participate, then you definitely couldn’t expect the bank to say that you’re guaranteed to clear in X days, because that would change the timeline in unpredictable ways.

          • hls2003 says:
            January 28, 2020 at 1:09 pm

            @CatCube

            I am trying to stay within my knowledge, but I believe the negotiable instruments portions should be applicable across all 50 states, though I haven’t checked them all. Given the need for a nationwide banking system, I would be shocked if the banking and commercial paper articles of the UCC have not been universally adopted. However, some states (notably Louisiana, which always has a bit of Gallic residue in its code) do not incorporate all the various articles of the UCC such as secured transactions.

            ETA: To answer directly, I don’t think there’s likely to be a difference in states on these particular issues. But if there is, then yes that would come into play.

        • Unsaintly says:
          January 27, 2020 at 12:22 pm

          Can anyone explain why it takes a few days/weeks to verify a check? Isn’t a simple “Does account X have amount Y in it?” query? What factors are slowing this down to the point where this becomes a problem?

          • Statismagician says:
            January 27, 2020 at 12:30 pm

            I’ve been told it’s not actually about verifying whether the writer of the check has enough money in their account, so much as it is about waiting for a convenient/profitable time for the source to pull it out of whatever the bank was using your money for (since they don’t want to just use the funds they’re required to keep on hand for obvious reasons) – not sure how accurate this is, though.

          • baconbits9 says:
            January 27, 2020 at 1:02 pm

            Can anyone explain why it takes a few days/weeks to verify a check? Isn‚Äôt a simple ‚ÄúDoes account X have amount Y in it?‚Äù query? What factors are slowing this down to the point where this becomes a problem?

            It’s more complicated than that. Lets say someone stole your checkbook and used it, there is a good chance you won’t notice that it has been stolen until after it has been actually used and the debit is drawn against your account. Would you want to use checks in a system where you had 24 or 48 hours after someone fraudulently used a check of yours to challenge that use? From a basic fraud discouraging viewpoint it isn’t great to just use a ‘enough money to cover the check’ as the only criteria.

            Additionally it is not always obvious how much money is in a bank account. A person could write multiple checks against their account that exceed the total available. Which ones get priority in the pecking order? The ones that arrive at the bank of the holder first? The ones that are deposited first or the ones that are dated first? Then there are electronic transactions that can be drawn against the same account, their are accounts that can be linked where your savings account acts as a backup for your checking account, and your account could have part of its value from another check that hasn’t cleared yet.

            Then of course there is the simple fact that tens of millions of payment transactions occur every single day, which requires some complicated logistics as well as lots of checks (no pun intended) on how many mistakes are being made.

          • zardoz says:
            January 27, 2020 at 5:14 pm

            The US financial system has a weird model where almost all transactions are revocable. There’s also very little computer security on anything. What there is is laughable (magstripes, 4-digit pins, etc.)

            The theory is that even though the computer security is terrible, very scary people will come after you if you exploit that fact. The system… works better than computer people think it should?

            A bunch of people hated all this revocability stuff, plus some of the politicization of payment processing. They created Bitcoin. But that has its own problems…

          • albatross11 says:
            January 27, 2020 at 10:50 pm

            There are different problems being described here.

            a. The normal situation is that I deposit a check, and it takes N days to clear. As best I can tell, the N days is the result of a negotiation between the state and banks who would like to be able to capture the interest on the money from checks in flight. There is no reason why the reconciliation of a check can’t be done electronically the moment it’s deposited at a bank, for any US bank at least, except that this would take away a source of revenue for a lot of banks. There’s certainly no technological bar to the banks reconciling things electronically within one business day.

            b. There’s also the situation where a check was fraudulent–for example, the account owner’s signature was forged on a stolen check. This might be detected long after the transaction has taken place, but it’s a fundamentally different problem–it doesn’t matter how long the float is on the checks. When a fraudulent transaction is detected, then someone’s going to get stuck with the bill, and everyone is going to try to pass it on to someone else.

            c. A fraudulent cashiers’ check (forged from a bank that didn’t actually issue it) is more like (a)–it’s something that the banks could clear electronically in realtime. I don’t know what the law is w.r.t. fraudulently-acquired cashiers’ checks (someone forges a check from someone else to get a cashier’s check, for example), but presumably everyone will be scrambling to see that someone else ends up paying the cost.

            d. It seems to me that for most of these cases (other than (b)), the bank which cashes the check is the entity that’s in the best situation to prevent the fraud. US banks don’t immediately clear checks from other US banks, not because there’s some technological reason why this would be hard, but because there’s a business reason to want to keep benefiting from the float of uncleared checks, and they certainly could do so. (Other kinds of funds transfers are cleared immediately.) Further, the bank is in a position to know about fraudulent kinds of transactions that a normal customer has never heard of, and could prevent many of them–for example, if I show up with a forged cashier’s check from some bank in another state, the bank could in principle check that with the issuing bank, whereas I really can’t. I think a good general rule is to put the burden of preventing fraud onto the side in the best position to prevent it, and that’s the bank that cashes the check.

            In the case of a cashier’s check that’s legitimate, but which the issuing bank was defrauded by a customer to get, ISTM that the issuing bank is in the best position to detect/prevent the fraud, so should probably bear the risk.

          • acymetric says:
            January 28, 2020 at 5:35 am

            If you make the bank totally liable for all of those, you make check fraud a lot more appealing.

          • LesHapablap says:
            January 28, 2020 at 11:14 am

            Albatross,

            My understanding is that there IS a technical reason that checks cannot be verified in less than a few weeks. That’s just what I heard when this question came up on a different forum, by some expert in the nitty gritty of the banking system. That was years ago and my have changed by now.

          • hls2003 says:
            January 28, 2020 at 12:14 pm

            Primarily the UCC.

          • Aapje says:
            January 29, 2020 at 12:25 am

            @zardoz

            The way to exploit despite reversibility is to have a strawperson take the money out of the financial system and pass it on to the final beneficiary.

            The strawperson is typically a person with little to lose like a homeless person or a naive youngster.

    • Ragged Clown says:
      January 27, 2020 at 3:41 am

      I came close to falling for a scam in the UK rental market a couple of years ago.

      The landlord wanted me to leave a deposit through airbnb because “that way your deposit would be safe”. I was suspicious and checked the SSL certificate on the airbnb payments page and, sure enough, it was a fake site. If I had not checked the certificate, there’s no way I would have spotted that the site was fake. I doubt that someone less tech-savvy would have spotted it.

      Absolutely no one was interested in hearing my story. Not the police, not Airbnb, and not the bank that hosted the scammer’s account.

      There’s a similar scam with deposit on a house purchase. When I bought a house about a year later, I received an email, purportedly from my solicitor (AKA lawyer), telling me to wire the funds to her account. The scammer knew every detail of the transaction.

      Fortunately my solicitor had forewarned me that this would happen and wrote her account on a piece of paper telling me “if someone asks you through email, it’s not me. It’s a scammer.”

      Again, no one was interested. It’s just one of those things that always happens when you buy a house in the UK. My solicitor was very concerned to tell me that it was not her company that was at fault but, otherwise not interested in pursuing it.

      I often wonder whether a crowd-sourced registry (something analagous to the sites that tell you that a website or email address is dodgy) could make progress in tracking down the scammers or, at least, in shaming the banks that allow the scammers to operate.

    • Deiseach says:
      January 27, 2020 at 4:44 am

      Perhaps naively, I‚Äôd think that this would be fairly easy to catch the criminals who are committing these crimes: post an ad for an expensive item on Craigslist, wait a few minutes for the scam texts to come in, negotiate until the scammer provides their own bank details or physical address, and then use this information to arrest them. Or just jump in midway when a potential victim comes to you with the scam in already progress.

      I think this is a naive view – think of all the scam blackmail emails that are going around, and are plainly all copied-and-pasted off an original script. The scammers buy these in bulk and spray them out, and some fish will fall for them. Why don’t the police get involved? Because it’s not really worth the time of the average policeman in an Irish town to try and get somebody in Russia or Eastern Europe or wherever the address is being bounced from tracked down and try to prove that they’re a criminal. The local police have local fish to fry.

      Trying to stop John Smith who sent a scam cheque is going to be like trying to dam Niagara Falls with a teaspoon. You’ll have to prove that it’s a scam in the first place, and even if you do get the source of the emails, then you’ll (a) find that ‘John Smith’ isn’t the real name, the address isn’t a real address, and even if you shut down this particular centre, they’ll just start up again under another name elsewhere and (b) the game is not worth the candle for the effort of prosecuting such small fish – trying to establish that a crime has really taken place, who has jurisdiction, where they’ll be tried – and that’s even if they manage to catch the scammer in the first place.

      They’re too many, it’s too easy to set up this scam, and you’d need a police officer for every user of the Internet to make sure that they don’t fall for such scams.

      I have to think they were wrong, but maybe there is another level of fraud happening and somehow the check was legitimate.

      If it was a legit cheque then it could be obtained by (a) steal a chequebook from a real person or business, use those because you the criminal don’t care if you’re burning through someone else’s money and you’re going to get the bulk of it anyway by using multiple cheques in a chain of scams (b) set up a bank account, deposit just enough into it to cover the cheque, write your cheque, then in between sending it off and the recipient cashing it, you withdraw your money from the bank so the cheque gets bounced (time it right so that your pigeon has already sent you the $5 grand they ‘owe’ you on the cheque before it comes back as rubber).

      • Dacyn says:
        January 27, 2020 at 9:38 am

        In scenario (a), why wouldn’t the scammer just deposit the check themselves? Then they would get 10K instead of 5K, for less work.

        • Edward Scizorhands says:
          January 28, 2020 at 10:13 am

          The scammer cannot deposit a stolen check into their own account. Because when it comes time to unwind it, the funds disappear from their own account.

          The scammers have, essentially, an unlimited supply of stolen bank account and stolen check information. They could steal all that money easily if they wanted to have it for a few days until it gets taken back. The limiting reagent is a sucker who will transform a transaction that can be unwound into one that cannot.

          That is why they want you to send them bitcoin or a traveller’s checks or cash or itunes gift cards.

      • acymetric says:
        January 27, 2020 at 9:44 am

        (b) set up a bank account, deposit just enough into it to cover the cheque, write your cheque, then in between sending it off and the recipient cashing it, you withdraw your money from the bank so the cheque gets bounced (time it right so that your pigeon has already sent you the $5 grand they ‚Äòowe‚Äô you on the cheque before it comes back as rubber).

        In the case of a cashiers check, the money is withdrawn as soon as the check is issued. Not possible to get the cashiers check and then withdraw the money from the bank before the check is cashed, the money is gone immediately. This is why cashiers checks (or money orders) are considered so “safe”. As long as the check isn’t a forgery/counterfeit, it is definitely backed by real money.

        There is also (c), which is what I would consider the most likely case if the check is legitimate: The check is legitimate, and backed by real money, but that money is from some illegal/corrupt enterprise and needs to be washed/laundered. Recruit someone to cash the check and then send the money to a third party via some mostly anonymous online scheme and you’ve potentially successfully laundered some money.

        • zardoz says:
          January 28, 2020 at 4:47 pm

          Why would anyone use a cashier’s check these days, though? As you said, it’s perfectly safe… unless it’s not. It is no more safe than a regular check. And the fact that it *appears* to be safe leads to a lot of people getting scammed.

          We already have wire transfers for cases where you need a transaction that is very hard to reverse. So maybe the solution is just to abolish cashier’s checks.

          Really paper checks of any kind are kind of silly in 2020. I’ve been told that Europeans find the US reliance on paper checks to be very strange….

          • Theodoric says:
            January 28, 2020 at 4:56 pm

            The fees for certified checks or cashier’s checks tend to be lower than the fees for wire transfers.

          • John Schilling says:
            January 29, 2020 at 7:50 am

            The most common threat model is not the clever scam artist with the seven-step master plan for getting away with the bank’s money, it’s the poor shmuck who just writes a personal check for more money than they have in the account because they either lost track or naively hoped to cover the difference before the check cleared. Cashiers’ checks, which unless outright forged guaranteed that the money is available and which are beyond amateur forging ability, are a simple, cheap and effective counter to that threat.

          • A Definite Beta Guy says:
            January 29, 2020 at 8:16 am

            What John said. When I worked commercial real estate, we would often ask for delinquent checks to be sent via cashier check because it has a higher probability of funds actually being there. A delinquent tenant sending a personal check is meaningless, because it often results in a bounced check.

            Wire Transfers are pretty expensive. Also, wire transfers absolutely suck from a cost allocation perspective because there is insufficient detail on the bank remittance to automatically allocate the cash, which is pretty essential. ACHs are more useful, but they typically involve more up-front work.

          • ana53294 says:
            January 29, 2020 at 8:36 am

            Well, in Spain, at least, banks stopped charging for wire transfers. UK banks don’t charge for wire transfers either (in GBP, that is).

            wire transfers absolutely suck from a cost allocation perspective because there is insufficient detail on the bank remittance to automatically allocate the cash,

            I don’t know how money is transferred in the US, but SEPA transfers in the EU suck for this. Whenever I do a SEPA transfer, I regularly need to send the receipt so they can find the transfer correctly. The old system was slower, but SEPA just doesn’t seem to send enough information to the receiver for them to parse who sent it.

          • hls2003 says:
            January 29, 2020 at 8:47 am

            As others have pointed out, it’s a lot more safe than a personal check. Unless there are very specific circumstances of an active scam going on – which generally requires a lot more effort than 99.99% of debtors are willing or able to put in – certified funds like a cashier’s check are secure.

            Bear in mind that under any legal regime, you can always go after the fraudster. The problem is that fraudsters always turn out to be either (a) gone, or (b) broke. The question is always which responsible party with money is going to bear the loss caused by the fraudster. They always theoretically can “recover” from the fraudster, but in practice that’s always a dry well.

          • zardoz says:
            January 30, 2020 at 9:07 pm

            > Wire Transfers are pretty expensive

            There’s not really a technical reason why they need to be, though, right? Some other posters in this thread gave the example of non-US banks offering wire transfers for no additional cost.

            I’m willing to believe that making US wire transfers cheaper would require updating some computer systems to handle additional volume. But it definitely seems feasible and would probably close some avenues of fraud.

            > Also, wire transfers absolutely suck from a cost allocation perspective because there is insufficient detail on the bank remittance to automatically allocate the cash, which is pretty essential. ACHs are more useful, but they typically involve more up front work.

            Can you clarify what you mean by this? Do you mean that there is no metadata about why the payment was sent?

          • LesHapablap says:
            January 30, 2020 at 9:39 pm

            I don’t know if the bank to bank transfers we use in NZ count as ‘wire transfers,’ but we have lots of room for metadata, with four fields:
            PAYEE ~20 digits
            PARTICULARS ~30 digits
            CODE unsure
            REFERENCE ~10 digits

            It’s enough so that Xero can match each one to an invoice automatically and the accounts person can just tick it off.

            Then on top of that there’s the amount of money and the date of the transfer, which helps to match it up as well.

            These bank transfers reduce transaction costs big time compared to checks, there’s just a lot less trust required to make things happen quickly when money gets transferred basically instantly.

  44. The Nybbler says:
    January 26, 2020 at 5:39 pm

    OK @bhauth, why should I believe your battery idea is any different than all the other battery ideas which have gone absolutely nowhere over the past 50 years? Obviously some have succeeded, most notably lithium-ion variants, but mostly when you hear about a battery breakthrough you can safely bet “it’ll never pan out”.

    • Brett says:
      January 26, 2020 at 6:06 pm

      I’m genuinely curious whether they’ve built a working test cell. Without one, it’s just paper chemistry – and even with a test cell, it’s a long way between there and a working commercial battery.

      • Bugmaster says:
        January 26, 2020 at 8:51 pm

        Agreed. In theory, lots of things work. In theory.

        • Elisha says:
          January 27, 2020 at 1:27 am

          The difference between practice and theory:
          In theory, there is no difference.

      • broblawsky says:
        January 27, 2020 at 6:17 am

        There’s nothing wrong with ideas on paper; that’s how all good ideas start. Also, this reminds me of a bunch of lithium-metal based superconcentrated electrolyte systems that have been published. I didn’t see anything that makes me think it’s completely implausible.

      • bhauth says:
        January 27, 2020 at 7:13 am

        There is a test cell which works as far as I can tell. Lifetime testing has not been done at this point.

        The tweet and this were aimed at groups researching battery technology, and at whatever people who can understand the merits of the design from just those pictures, not at you. Battery research seems to have sizeable budgets and few remaining avenues for substantial improvements, so my thinking was that SSC + whitequark may be enough for some groups to test something with no obviously wrong parts, even if it’s difficult to understand everything involved. That’s what’d be necessary in any case, because reported results from a test cell somewhere else shouldn’t be considered trustworthy in general. In many ways, high-level credentials and connections are more important than a working prototype.

        The path from a lab to commercial application is typically long, but that’s a matter of unsolved or unforseen tertiary problems to be solved, and of the time it takes to handle internal politics for the necessary investments, which means it can’t be estimated with a standardized formula. (Why do new chemical processes need a pilot plant stage? They don’t; BASF often doesn’t do pilot plants. The problem is that too many chemists working on a laboratory scale are delusional or ignorant about costs at a larger scale, and a pilot plant filters them out.)

        I also see the stories in popular media about “battery breakthroughs” and I can generally tell what the problems are.

        • Bugmaster says:
          January 27, 2020 at 11:38 am

          In many ways, high-level credentials and connections are more important than a working prototype.

          Is that actually true ? It’s hard to argue with a working prototype (assuming one is allowed to fully examine it). You don’t need to argue whose credentials are higher or who’s got more tenure or whatever — you can just hook up a multimeter to it, you know ?

          • bhauth says:
            January 27, 2020 at 1:18 pm

            1) If you just email people who could seriously pursue new battery technology and ask them to look at your test cell, it’s not like they’ll enthusiastically agree. Their personal assistant will probably delete the email before they even see it.

            2) A prototype probably isn’t going to have better energy density as a complete black-box system than a high-quality commercial battery. If you’re not going to look at the actual chemistry, then someone could just put a lithium-ion battery in a box and claim it contains new tech – kind of like how Theranos was using existing blood testing equipment and claiming they were doing something new.

            3) Given adequate specific energy and energy density for a major application such as electric cars, the key issue is really production cost at a large scale, and predicting that requires understanding both the system and manufacturing technology. Investors have (probably correctly) given up on making that kind of technical evaluation, so they depend on credentials of founders (and they generally defer to the university system’s credential ranking) and/or the prestige of earlier investors.

            The bigger the investment needed to actually see whether large-scale production is viable, the bigger the credentials you need to do a startup. In the case of batteries, you’d pretty much need to be a Caltech professor (or something comparable), or somehow get a connection to a prestigious investor (like Danielle Fong meeting Bill Gates and Nathan Myrvold at a party), or be independently wealthy (like Elon Musk).

            But like I said, there’s a lot of money going into battery research, and at the moment there’s something of a shortage of leads to follow within existing research programs.

          • Bugmaster says:
            January 27, 2020 at 7:31 pm

            If your battery doesn’t have better energy density than commercial offerings, than what’s your advantage ? Is it cheaper to build, less polluting, or what ? From my perspective as a layman, saying “physical prototypes don’t matter because we have all these endorsements from multiple Ph.D.s” is no better than saying “our magic black box is totally revolutionary, just don’t look inside”. It sounds quite fishy either way. Theranos had fantastically credentialed founders, too, you know ?

          • bhauth says:
            January 28, 2020 at 9:03 am

            You misread my comment.

          • Aapje says:
            January 29, 2020 at 1:16 am

            @Bugmaster

            What he’s saying is that the true proof of the pudding is what you are able to mass produce, which needs very extensive and advanced expertise to predict, even if one already has a laboratory prototype. So investors trust people with a proven track record at doing so, as well as people with high status in universities, neither of which bhauth or others associated with this project are.

            So his goal is to convince such high status people that the idea has high potential, which will unlock the moneys.

    • Byrel Mitchell says:
      January 27, 2020 at 8:40 am

      That’s pretty much true in every field. When you hear about any dramatic innovation (say: a cancer cure, or an Alzheimer’s treatment) the safe bet is that it won’t replicate, or it’ll fail in clinicals due to toxicity, or SOMETHING.

      It’s still worth it for the <10% that make it. Everyone has to start at 'this thing looks promising and would be better than current technologies.'

      • bhauth says:
        January 27, 2020 at 1:22 pm

        I personally know professors who’ve worked on Alzheimer’s and cancer research projects that they knew were dead ends, because that’s what they got grants for.

      • bhauth says:
        January 29, 2020 at 3:09 pm

        By the way, since you seem to be a DCSS player, you should try bcrawl sometime.

  • Advertisements

  • Giving What We Can is a charitable movement promoting giving some of your money to the developing world or other worthy causes. If you're interested in this, consider taking their Pledge as a formal and public declaration of intent.

    AISafety.com hosts a Skype reading group Wednesdays at 19:45 UTC, reading new and old articles on different aspects of AI Safety. We start with a presentation of a summary of the article, and then discuss in a friendly atmosphere.

    Beeminder's an evidence-based willpower augmention tool that collects quantifiable data about your life, then helps you organize it into commitment mechanisms so you can keep resolutions. They've also got a blog about what they're doing here

    Norwegian founders with an international team on a mission to offer the equivalent of a Norwegian social safety net globally available as a membership. Currently offering travel medical insurance for nomads, and global health insurance for remote teams.

    The Charter Cities Institute is working on ways governments can set up special zones with unique legal institutions. Learn more about how this could help tackle problems from global poverty to climate change.

    Metaculus is a platform for generating crowd-sourced predictions about the future, especially science and technology. If you're interested in testing yourself and contributing to their project, check out their questions page

    Altruisto is a browser extension so that when you shop online, a portion of the money you pay goes to effective charities (no extra cost to you). Just install an extension and when you buy something, people in poverty will get medicines, bed nets, or financial aid.

    Jane Street is a quantitative trading firm with a focus on technology and collaborative problem solving. We're always hiring talented programmers, traders, and researchers and have internships and fulltime positions in New York, London, and Hong Kong. No background in finance required.

    B4X is a free and open source developer tool that allows users to write apps for Android, iOS, and more.

    80,000 Hours researches different problems and professions to help you figure out how to do as much good as possible. Their free career guide show you how to choose a career that's fulfilling and maximises your contribution to solving the world's most pressing problems.

    Support Slate Star Codex on Patreon. I have a day job and SSC gets free hosting, so don't feel pressured to contribute. But extra cash helps pay for contest prizes, meetup expenses, and me spending extra time blogging instead of working.

    MealSquares is a "nutritionally complete" food that contains a balanced diet worth of nutrients in a few tasty easily measurable units. Think Soylent, except zero preparation, made with natural ingredients, and looks/tastes a lot like an ordinary scone.

    Dr. Laura Baur is a psychiatrist with interests in literature review, reproductive psychiatry, and relational psychotherapy; see her website for more. Note that due to conflict of interest she doesn't treat people in the NYC rationalist social scene.

    The Effective Altruism newsletter provides monthly updates on the highest-impact ways to do good and help others.

    Substack is a blogging site that helps writers earn money and readers discover articles they'll like.

    The COVID-19 Forecasting Project at the University of Oxford is making advanced pandemic simulations of 150+ countries available to the public, and also offer pro-bono forecasting services to decision-makers.

    Seattle Anxiety Specialists are a therapy practice helping people overcome anxiety and related mental health issues (eg GAD, OCD, PTSD) through evidence based interventions and self-exploration. Check out their free anti-anxiety guide here

    .
